feels.name: Sadness
feels.quote: Oh, my dear! the bitter, bitter crying she had when she was alone; and at last, as she grew weaker, she could not keep her tears in when Deborah or me was by, and would give us message after message for Peter...

feels.name: Love
feels.quote: And she and Deborah sat by my bedside; I knew by the looks of each that there had been no news of Peter—no awful, ghastly news, which was what I most had dreaded in my dull state between sleeping and waking.

feels.name: Grief
feels.quote: That spring day was the last time he ever saw his mother’s face.

feels.name: Acceptance
feels.quote: And only think, love! the very day after her death—for she did not live quite a twelvemonth after Peter went away—the very day after—came a parcel for her from India—from her poor boy.

feels.name: Regret
feels.quote: And then again, when I sit by myself, and all the house is still, I think I hear his step coming up the street, and my heart begins to flutter and beat; but the sound always goes past—and Peter never comes.

feels.name: Modesty
feels.quote: She was quite unconscious of it herself, and looked at us, with bland satisfaction.

causedByEvent.name: Visiting Miss Matty and Miss Deborah

feels.name: Embarrassment
feels.quote: She was very much absorbed in her errand, which she delivered herself of with an oppressive modesty that found vent in endless apologies.
